Author: NutellaLicka#4241
Content:
I am in need of some troubleshooting help. I am using knomp sapling branch on the RKT chain and i'm regularly getting this output.
```2018-12-12 21:10:18 [Pool]      [rkt] (Thread 1) Submitted Block using submitblock successfully to daemon instance(s)
2018-12-12 21:10:18 [Pool]      [rkt] (Thread 1) We thought a block was found but it was rejected by the daemon, share data: {"job":"ccea","ip":"::ffff:127.0.0.1","port":10000,"worker":"zs1wqnm9d8yvwgn89l2rc5n3xc773x9mtpx6eklg5r6qzsxkwf92vhwzd57kvstnca7hqaqx8sk3yg.ballgag","height":24146,"difficulty":5,"shareDiff":"6.28810795","blockDiff":1.165926502,"blockDiffActual":1.165926502,"blockHash":"000145b1b419f65485f076f3e8cb00fa6f62350d0855a8288123ac64abb80700","error":{"unknown":"check coin daemon logs"}}```

The coin daemon log is always:
```2018-12-12 11:06:46 CheckBlockHeader komodo_check_deposit errorERROR: ProcessNewBlock: CheckBlock FAILED```

I am still finding blocks regularly, and this rejected block occurs when I'd expect to have found one(I am one of two miners on the network). It may happen a handful of times before it actually finds a block. Has anyone seen this daemon output error before?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @NutellaLicka edit pool.js in stratum-pool/lib/ to print `blockHex` to console

Author: Alright#0419
Content: then get the blockhex and use `komodo-cli -ac_name=RKT submitblock <blockhex>` and check debug.log and stdout to see what error the daemon throws

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Ah I guess that won't quite work unless you're doing it on your own chain that you can stop

Author: Alright#0419
Content: or you do `invalidateblock` on the public block found at that point

Author: NutellaLicka#4241
Content: I could get the chain stopped, should I try that?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: you can just force your node to fork with `invalidateblock`

Author: Alright#0419
Content: first get the stratum to print hex of the block

Author: Alright#0419
Content: then wait for that error to happen, wait for the next block to come in and do `invalidateblock <blockhash>` on it, your node will now be on it's own fork

Author: Alright#0419
Content: then take the blockhex outputted from the stratum and do `submitblock <blockhex>`

Author: Alright#0419
Content: that should give you an error in stdout, debug.log or shell you're doing it in

Author: Alright#0419
Content: if you get that far, let me know and I'll help you pin down what consensus rule it's violating

Author: NutellaLicka#4241
Content: Sweet thanks, I'll get on it
